Input-output theory for spin-photon coupling in Si double quantum dots

M. Benito,1 X. Mi,2 J. M. Taylor,3 J. R. Petta,2 and Guido Burkard1 1Department of Physics, University of Konstanz, D-78457 Konstanz, Germany 2Department of Physics, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544, USA 3Joint Quantum Institute/NIST, College Park, Maryland 20742, USA
Abstract

The interaction of qubits via microwave frequency photons enables long-distance qubit-qubit coupling and facilitates the realization of a large-scale quantum processor. However, qubits based on electron spins in semiconductor quantum dots have proven challenging to couple to microwave photons. In this theoretical work we show that a sizable coupling for a single electron spin is possible via spin-charge hybridization using a magnetic field gradient in a silicon double quantum dot. Based on parameters already shown in recent experiments, we predict optimal working points to achieve a coherent spin-photon coupling, an essential ingredient for the generation of long-range entanglement. Furthermore, we employ input-output theory to identify observable signatures of spin-photon coupling in the cavity output field, which may provide guidance to the experimental search for strong coupling in such spin-photon systems and opens the way to cavity-based readout of the spin qubit.

I Introduction

Building a practical solid state quantum processor necessitates a flexible scheme of coupling individual qubits such that a 2D array of qubits, or even a network with connectivity between arbitrary pairs of qubits (â€œall-to-allâ€ connectivity), may be achieved FowlerÂ etÂ al. (2012); CÃ³rcolesÂ etÂ al. (2015); DebnathÂ etÂ al. (2016). For superconducting qubits, entanglement of qubits separated by macroscopic distances has been demonstrated using the approach of circuit quantum electrodynamics (cQED)Â RaimondÂ etÂ al. (2001); BlaisÂ etÂ al. (2004); ChildressÂ etÂ al. (2004); CottetÂ etÂ al. , whereby photons confined inside microwave frequency cavities serve as mobile carriers of quantum information that mediate long-range qubit interactions MajerÂ etÂ al. (2007); SillanpaaÂ etÂ al. (2007). Compared to superconducting qubits, qubits based on spins of electrons in semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) have the virtue of long lifetimes (T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1}) that can be on the order of seconds for Si YangÂ etÂ al. (2013); ZwanenburgÂ etÂ al. (2013). On the other hand, the coupling of spin qubits has remained limited by nearest neighbor exchange interactions with typical distances <<100 nm PettaÂ etÂ al. (2005); VeldhorstÂ etÂ al. (2015). The development of a spin-cQED architecture in which spin qubits are coherently coupled to microwave frequency photons is therefore a critical goal which would enable a spin-based quantum processor with full connectivity.

To transfer quantum states between a spin qubit and a cavity photon with high fidelity, it is necessary to achieve the strong-coupling regime in which the spin-photon coupling gssubscriptğ‘”ğ‘ g_{s} exceeds both the cavity decay rate Îºğœ…\kappa and the spin decoherence rate Î³ssubscriptğ›¾ğ‘ \gamma_{s} RaimondÂ etÂ al. (2001); ImamoÄŸlu (2009). While demonstrations of strong coupling have already been made with superconducting qubits WallraffÂ etÂ al. (2004) and semiconductor charge qubits MiÂ etÂ al. (2017a); StockklauserÂ etÂ al. (2017); BruhatÂ etÂ al. , such a task has proven challenging for a single spin due to its small magnetic dipole, which results in coupling rates that are less than 1 kHz and too slow compared to typical spin dephasing rates ImamoÄŸlu (2009); AmsÃ¼ssÂ etÂ al. (2011); BienfaitÂ etÂ al. (2016); EichlerÂ etÂ al. (2017). An alternative route toward strong spin-photon coupling involves hybridizing the spin and charge states of QD electrons ChildressÂ etÂ al. (2004); TrifÂ etÂ al. (2008); CottetÂ andÂ Kontos (2010); HuÂ etÂ al. (2012); BeaudoinÂ etÂ al. (2016). The relatively large electric susceptibilities of the electron charge states lead to an effective spin-photon coupling rate gssubscriptğ‘”ğ‘ g_{s} on the order of MHz, as recently demonstrated by a carbon nanotube double quantum dot (DQD) device ViennotÂ etÂ al. (2015). However, spin-charge hybridization also renders spin qubits susceptible to charge noise, which has up to now prevented the strong coupling regime from being reached with a single spinÂ ViennotÂ etÂ al. (2015).

Here we analyze a scheme for strong spin-photon coupling using a semiconductor DQD placed in the inhomogeneous magnetic field of a micromagnet, first outlined in Ref.Â HuÂ etÂ al. (2012). We extend this previous work by predicting a complete map of the effective spin-photon coupling rate gssubscriptğ‘”ğ‘ g_{s} and spin decoherence rate Î³ssubscriptğ›¾ğ‘ \gamma_{s}. This allows us to find optimal working points for coherent spin-photon coupling. We further present detailed calculations of the cavity transmission and identify experimentally observable signatures of spin-photon coupling. Importantly, we predict that the strong-coupling regime between a single spin and a single photon is achievable in Si using values of the charge-cavity vacuum Rabi frequency gcsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘g_{c} and charge decoherence rate Î³csubscriptğ›¾ğ‘\gamma_{c} from recent experiments MiÂ etÂ al. (2017b, a).

The physical system consists of a gate-defined Si DQD that is embedded in a superconducting cavity; see Fig.Â 1. The electric-dipole interaction couples the electronic charge states in the DQD to the cavity electric field. The introduction of an inhomogeneous magnetic field, as sketched in Fig.Â 1, hybridizes the charge states of a DQD electron with its spin states, indirectly coupling the cavity electric field to the electron spin.

V Results

Assuming that the cavity frequency is tuned to the predominantly spin-like transition, which is 0â†”1â†”010\leftrightarrow 1 (0â†”2â†”020\leftrightarrow 2) for cosâ¡Î¦>0Î¦0\cos\Phi>0 (cosâ¡Î¦<0Î¦0\cos\Phi<0), the effective spin-cavity coupling strength will be given by gs=gcâ€‹|d01â€‹(2)|subscriptğ‘”ssubscriptğ‘”ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘012g_{\mathrm{s}}=g_{c}|d_{01(2)}|.

V.3 Effective coupling map

Before calculating the effect of the Si DQD on the cavity transmission Ağ´A, let us estimate the magnitude of the coupling gssubscriptğ‘”sg_{\mathrm{s}}. For Î©>BzÎ©subscriptğµğ‘§\Omega>B_{z} (Î©<BzÎ©subscriptğµğ‘§\Omega<B_{z}), 0â†”1â†”010\leftrightarrow 1 (0â†”2â†”020\leftrightarrow 2) is predominantly a spin transition, therefore we can obtain a map for the effective coupling by using gs=gcâ€‹|d01â€‹(2)|subscriptğ‘”ssubscriptğ‘”ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘012g_{\mathrm{s}}=g_{c}|d_{01(2)}|; see Fig.Â 3Â (a). As the value of Î©Î©\Omega approaches Bzsubscriptğµğ‘§B_{z}, Î¦Î¦\Phi tends to Ï€/2ğœ‹2\pi/2 and the coupling is maximized. However, in this regime, due to strong spin-charge hybridization, the charge nature of the transition increases [see Eqs.Â (13) andÂ (14)] and with it the decoherence rate increases, preventing the system from reaching strong coupling. In the following we show that the ratio of the coupling rate to the total decoherence rate can be optimized by working away from maximal coupling. In particular the strong-coupling regime for the spin can be achieved.

At this point, Ï‡01â€‹d01+Ï‡02â€‹d02â‰ƒ0similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğœ’01subscriptğ‘‘01subscriptğœ’02subscriptğ‘‘020\chi_{01}d_{01}+\chi_{02}d_{02}\simeq 0.

In the usual scenario of a two-level system coupled to a photonic cavity, strong coupling results in light-matter hybridization, as evidenced in the observation of vacuum Rabi splitting in the cavity transmission spectrum when the qubit transition frequency matches the cavity frequency. The two vacuum Rabi normal modes are separated by a frequency corresponding to the characteristic rate of the light-matter interaction, and the linewidth of each mode reflects the average decoherence rate of light and matterÂ ThompsonÂ etÂ al. (1992). In Fig.Â 5Â (a), we show the absolute value of the transmission, |A|ğ´|A|, as a function of the magnetic field Bzsubscriptğµğ‘§B_{z} and the driving frequency relative to Ï‰csubscriptğœ”c\omega_{\mathrm{c}}, Î”0subscriptÎ”0\Delta_{0}, at Ïµ=0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon=0. The phase gives similar information (not shown). When the driving frequency is near the cavity frequency, Î”0âˆ¼0similar-tosubscriptÎ”00\Delta_{0}\sim 0, two peaks emerge in the cavity transmission, signifying the strong-coupling regime. In Figs.Â 5Â (b) andÂ (c) we show the horizontal and vertical cuts of this figure at Î”0=0subscriptÎ”00\Delta_{0}=0 and Bz=Bzressubscriptğµğ‘§superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘§resB_{z}=B_{z}^{\mathrm{res}}, respectively, where Bzressuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘§resB_{z}^{\mathrm{res}}, given by Eq.Â (31), ensures E1âˆ’E0=Ï‰csubscriptğ¸1subscriptğ¸0subscriptğœ”cE_{1}-E_{0}=\omega_{\mathrm{c}}. In Fig.Â 5Â (b) we observe the same interference effect seen in Fig.Â 4, and in Fig.Â 5Â (c) the vacuum Rabi splitting. As indicated with a red arrow, the effective coupling, related to the separation between the two peaks, corresponds to gs/2â€‹Ï€âˆ¼5â€‹MHzsimilar-tosubscriptğ‘”s2ğœ‹5MHzg_{\mathrm{s}}/2\pi\sim 5\,\mathrm{MHz} and the parameters under consideration can be readily achieved in Si DQD architectures (MiÂ etÂ al., 2017b, a).

In the present case, we are dealing with a three-level system, where the spin-photon coupling is mediated by the spin-charge hybridizationÂ ChildressÂ etÂ al. (2004). The three-level system structure explains not only the interference but also why the width and position of the two resonance peaks in Fig.Â 5Â (c) is slightly asymmetric. As expected, this asymmetry is more apparent as gcsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘g_{c} increases, which is shown in Fig.Â 6. In sectionÂ V.6, we reduce the problem to an equivalent two-level system to be able to characterize the spin-photon coupling within the standard formalism utilized for the Jaynes-Cummings model.

V.5 Broadening due to nuclear spins

The estimated value of the spin decoherence rate induced by the spin-charge hybridization is of the order Î³s/2â€‹Ï€âˆ¼1âˆ’10â€‹MHzsimilar-tosubscriptğ›¾s2ğœ‹110MHz\gamma_{\mathrm{s}}/2\pi\sim 1-10\,\mathrm{MHz}. Another source of decoherence in Si QDs is the effect of the Si29superscriptSi29{}^{29}\mathrm{Si} nuclear spins which surround the electron spin. As their evolution is slow compared to the typical time scale of the electronic processes, the nuclear spins effectively produce a random magnetic field which slightly influences the total magnetic field on the DQD. This small perturbation of the magnetic field, Bztot=Bz+Bznucsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘§totsubscriptğµğ‘§superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘§nucB_{z}^{\mathrm{tot}}=B_{z}+B_{z}^{\mathrm{nuc}}, will modify the frequency Ï‰c+Î”0subscriptğœ”csubscriptÎ”0\omega_{\mathrm{c}}+\Delta_{0} of the two vacuum Rabi normal modes, as can be extracted from Fig.Â 5Â (a). The nuclear magnetic field follows a Gaussian distribution with average zero and standard deviation Ïƒnucsuperscriptğœnuc\sigma^{\mathrm{nuc}}. In this way, a Gaussian profile is superimposed to the Lorentzian profile of the resonances and the final width also depends on Ïƒnucsuperscriptğœnuc\sigma^{\mathrm{nuc}}. At the point with maximum spin-charge hybridization (Î©âˆ¼Bzsimilar-toÎ©subscriptğµğ‘§\Omega\sim B_{z}), this effect is negligible because the decoherence is dominated by charge decoherence. Away from this point, the two broadening mechanisms have to be combined, resulting in a Voigt profileÂ OlverÂ etÂ al. (2010). The spin dephasing times in natural Si are âˆ¼1â€‹Î¼â€‹ssimilar-toabsent1ğœ‡s\sim 1\,\mu\mathrm{s}, which corresponds approximately to a standard deviation of Ïƒnuc/2â€‹Ï€âˆ¼0.3â€‹MHzsimilar-tosuperscriptğœnuc2ğœ‹0.3MHz\sigma^{\mathrm{nuc}}/2\pi\sim 0.3\,\mathrm{MHz} for the nuclear magnetic field distributionÂ KawakamiÂ etÂ al. (2014). According to Eq.Â (30), the positions of the two vacuum Rabi modes are given by the solutions of the equation

Neglecting input noise terms for the charge relaxation which will be irrelevant for our linear response theory, these equations read

In Fig.Â 7 we provide a map of the coupling strength via the quantity gs/Î“subscriptğ‘”sÎ“g_{\mathrm{s}}/\Gamma, with the magnetic field adjusted to the resonance condition. This map indicates the optimum working points that create a strong spin-photon interaction that overcomes the decoherence.

VI Conclusions

In conclusion, we detail the conditions for achieving strong coupling between a single electron spin and a microwave cavity photon, which eventually would allow long distance spin-spin coupling and long-range spin-qubit gates. Non-local quantum gates may also facilitate quantum error correction within a fault-tolerant architecture, and have already been used for this purpose in other systemsÂ TaylorÂ etÂ al. (2005); ReedÂ etÂ al. (2012); WaldherrÂ etÂ al. (2014).

Our analysis on the dynamics of the full hybrid silicon-cQED system confirms that, with the recent advances in Si DQDs fabrication and control, a spin-photon coupling of more than 10â€‹MHz10MHz10\,\mathrm{MHz} with a sufficiently low spin decoherence rate is achievable with this setup, potentially allowing the strong-coupling regimeÂ ZajacÂ etÂ al. (2016); MiÂ etÂ al. (2017a). In such a regime, the cavity not only can act as a mediator of spin-spin coupling but also enables cavity-based readout of the spin qubit stateÂ KawakamiÂ etÂ al. (2014); TakedaÂ etÂ al. (2016). Interestingly, the strong-coupling regime for the spin-cavity coupling may be attained even when the coupling strength of the charge-cavity coupling can not overcome the charge decoherence rate.

Although here we have focused on the coupling of a single electron spin to a single photon, the implementation of proposals for other type of spin qubits with more than one electron BurkardÂ andÂ Imamoglu (2006); JinÂ etÂ al. (2012); TaylorÂ etÂ al. (2013); RussÂ andÂ Burkard (2015) seems feasible with the present technology in Si QDs.

Appendix C Characterization of the spin-photon coupling

In this appendix, we detail the calculation of the strong-coupling condition for our two-level equivalent system. To examine this, we describe the spin-cavity interaction (Eqs.Â (39) andÂ (40)) with an effective Hamiltonian in the one-excitation manifold.
